We recite to you from the news of Moses and Pharaoh in truth for a people who believe.

Indeed, Pharaoh exalted himself in the land and made its people into factions, oppressing a sector among them, slaughtering their [newborn] sons and keeping their females alive. Indeed, he was of the corrupters.
And We wanted to confer favor upon those who were oppressed in the land and make them leaders and make them inheritors
And establish them in the land and show Pharaoh and [his minister] Haman and their soldiers through them that which they had feared.

And We inspired to the mother of Moses, "Suckle him; but when you fear for him, cast him into the river and do not fear and do not grieve. Indeed, We will return him to you and will make him [one] of the messengers."
And the family of Pharaoh picked him up [out of the river] so that he would become to them an enemy and a [cause of] grief. Indeed, Pharaoh and Haman and their soldiers were deliberate sinners.
And the wife of Pharaoh said, "[He will be] a comfort of the eye for me and for you. Do not kill him; perhaps he may benefit us, or we may adopt him as a son." And they perceived not.
And the heart of Moses' mother became empty [of all else]. She was about to disclose [the matter concerning] him had We not bound fast her heart that she would be of the believers.
And she said to his sister, "Follow him"; so she watched him from a distance while they perceived not.
And We had prevented from him [all] wet nurses before, so she said, "Shall I direct you to a household that will be responsible for him for you while they are to him [for his upbringing] sincere?"
So We restored him to his mother that she might be content and not grieve and that she would know that the promise of Allah is true. But most of the people do not know.
And when he attained his full strength and was [mentally] mature, We bestowed upon him judgement and knowledge. And thus do We reward the doers of good.

And he entered the city at a time of inattention by its people and found therein two men fighting: one from his faction and one from among his enemy. And the one from his faction called for help to him against the one from his enemy, so Moses struck him and [unintentionally] killed him. [Moses] said, "This is from the work of Satan. Indeed, he is a manifest, misleading enemy."

a.g: So he watered [their flocks] for them; then he went back to the shade and said, "My Lord, indeed I am, for whatever good You would send down to me, in need."

One of the women said, "O my father, hire him. Indeed, the best one you can hire is the strong and the trustworthy."

He said, "Indeed, I wish to wed you one of these, my two daughters, on [the condition] that you serve me for eight years; but if you complete ten, it will be [as a favor] from you. And I do not wish to put you in difficulty. You will find me, if Allah wills, from among the righteous."
[Moses] said, "That is [established] between me and you. Whichever of the two terms I complete - there is no injustice to me, and Allah, over what we say, is Witness."

ğŸ“– Vol 4: Patience and Gratitude
Indeed, the clarification of the virtue of renunciation [zuhd]. Allah, the Exalted, says: "**These will be given their reward twice for what they patiently endured**" and in the interpretation, it has come concerning renunciation of the world [dunya]. And He, the Mighty and Majestic, says: "**Indeed, We have made that which is on the earth an adornment for it that We may test them as to which of them is best in deed.**" It is said: its meaning is 'which of them is most renunciant [azhad] of it,' thus describing renunciation [zuhd] as being among the best of deeds. And He, the Exalted, says: "**Whoever desires the harvest of the Hereafter [akhirah], We increase for him in his harvest; and whoever desires the harvest of the world [dunya], We give him thereof, but he has no share in the Hereafter [akhirah].**" And He, the Exalted, says: "**And do not extend your eyes toward that by which We have given enjoyment to [some] categories of them, [its being but] the splendor of worldly life [hayat al-dunya] by which We test them. And the provision of your Lord is better and more enduring.**" And He, the Exalted, says: "**[They are] those who prefer the worldly life [hayat al-dunya] over the Hereafter [akhirah].**" Thus, He described the disbelievers with that, so its understood meaning is that the believer is the one characterized by its opposite, which is that he prefers the Hereafter [akhirah] over the worldly life [hayat al-dunya].

ğŸ“– Vol 3: Condemnation of Self-Delusion
And as for the knowledge (Ma'rifah) through clarification and proof, it is to know the aspect of corruption of this analogy (Qiyas) that the Satan (Shaytan) organized in his heart (Qalb), for every deluded one has a cause for his delusion, and that cause is evidence and every evidence is a type of analogy that occurs in the soul (Nafs) and produces tranquility towards it even if its possessor is not aware of it nor capable of organizing it with the words of the scholars. So the analogy that the Satan organized has two foundations: "one" that the worldly life (Dunya) is cash and the Hereafter (Akhirah) is credit, and this is correct; "the other" is his statement: Indeed, cash is better than credit, and this is the place of deception, for the matter is not so, rather if the cash is like the credit in amount and purpose then it is better, but if it is less than it then the credit is better. For the deluded disbeliever (Kafir) spends in his trade a dirham to receive ten on credit, yet he does not spend a dirham to receive ten on credit in the Hereafter, and this is pure ignorance (Jahl), for if he knew that what is with Allah is better and more lasting, he would prefer credit over cash. And to this meaning Allah the Exalted pointed with His saying: "And whatever you have been given of anything, then it is the enjoyment of the worldly life and its adornment. And what is with Allah is better and more lasting. So will you not use intellect?" So He made clear that what is with Allah is better and more lasting, so whoever prefers what is inferior over what is superior has abandoned the best, and this is delusion itself.

Vol 4: Watchfulness and Self-Examination
If the servant (Al-'Abd) is free from obligatory duties (Al-Fara'id) and capable of virtues (Al-Fada'il), he should seek the best deeds to occupy himself with them. For whoever misses additional profit while capable of attaining it is cheated, and profits are gained through the merits of virtues. Thus, the servant takes from his worldly life for his Hereafter, as Allah the Exalted said: 'And do not forget your share of the world (Al-Dunya).' All of this is only possible with patience for a single hour (Saa'ah). For the hours are three: a past hour that does not burden the servant however it passed, in hardship or ease; a future hour that has not yet comeâ€”the servant does not know if he will live to it or not, nor does he know what Allah decrees in it; and a present hour in which he should strive against his Soul (Nafs) and observe his Lord (Rabb) in it. If the second hour does not come to him, he will not regret the loss of this hour; and if the second hour comes to him, he fulfills his right from it as he fulfilled from the first. And he should not extend his hope for fifty years, making the resolve for observation (Al-Muraqabah) in it prolonged; rather, he should be a child of his moment as if in his last breaths, for perhaps it is his last breath and he does not know. And if it is possible to be his last breath, he should be in a state where he does not dislike that death overtakes him in that condition.

It is not difficult for the possessor of snow to sell it for jewels and pearls. Such is the example of this world [al-dunya] and the Hereafter [al-akhirah].
